topic: A Family Member You Are Proud Of

q1.html:
Describe a family member who you are proud of. You should say:
Who this person is
When this happened
What this person did
And explain why you felt proud.

To begin with, I want to talk about my uncle, who is an accomplished (有造诣的 / 成功的) doctor, because I truly look up to (敬仰) him. Actually, he is a very diligent (勤奋的) person who always puts others first. Whenever his patients need help, he is considerate (体贴的) and completely selfless (无私的). In fact, he has a generous (慷慨的) nature and essentially has a heart of gold (心地善良). For example, he will always go the extra mile (加倍努力) to ensure (确保) everyone is safe. I think, seeing his devoted (挚爱的 / 忠诚的) attitude is highly inspiring (鼓舞人心的) to me. To be honest, I felt so proud when he saved a life last year.

q2.html:
Describe a family member who has achieved something great. You should say:
Who the person is
What the achievement was
How they achieved it
And explain how their achievement influenced you.

q3.html:
Describe a family member you admire for their personality. You should say:
Who this person is
What kind of personality they have
How they treat others
And explain why you admire their character.

q1.html:
What would children do to make their parents proud?

Op Generally speaking, children can make their parents proud by excelling in their education, as academic success is highly valued. Re This is because, parents often sacrifice (牺牲) time to instill (灌输 (价值观)) good study habits in their kids. Ex For instance, when a student achieves top grades, parents truly appreciate (感激 / 欣赏) the immense effort shown.

q2.html:
What did you do to make your parents proud when you were young?

Op Looking back, I made my parents proud when I decided to follow in someone's footsteps (继承衣钵 / 效法) by learning the piano. Re The primary reason is that, my mother is a musician who wanted me to share her passion. Ex As an example, performing well at my first recital (独奏会) proved that the apple doesn't fall far from the tree (有其父必有其子).

q3.html:
What advantages of yours make you proud?

Op From my perspective (观点 / 视角), I am most proud of my ability to maintain peace, because it creates harmony (和谐) in my social circles. Re This is largely due to the fact that, resolving disputes (争端) requires immense patience and excellent communication skills. Ex For example, whenever my classmates argue, I step in to offer calm guidance (指导) to resolve the issue.

q4.html:
When was the last time that you felt proud of yourself?

Op To be specific, I felt incredibly proud last month when I helped bridge a generation gap (代沟) between my grandfather and me. Re This was significant because, younger people and older relatives often struggle to comprehend (理解) each other. Ex As an illustration, I taught him how to use a smartphone, which greatly improved our daily conversations.

q5.html:
How does family pride contribute to the stability of a society?

Op It is widely acknowledged that, family pride creates a strong foundation, which ultimately leads to a more stable community. Re The core reason is that, people naturally want to protect and support their own flesh and blood (骨肉 / 亲人). Ex For instance, families that respect each other are far less likely to commit crimes (犯罪) in public areas.

q6.html:
Do you think the definition of "success" within families has changed between the past and the present?

Op Undeniably, the definition of success has evolved (演变), as modern families value personal happiness over just financial wealth. Re In the past, success simply meant being the main breadwinner (养家糊口的人) to provide basic necessities (必需品). Ex Today, however, achieving a healthy work-life balance and pursuing individual passions are seen as equally important.

q1.html:
Describe a foreign country where you'd like to work for a short time. You should say:
Where you would like to go
What kind of work you want to do
When you would like to go
And explain why you want to work in that place.

To be honest, I would love to work in London, which is a cosmopolitan (世界性的 / 国际化的) city, because it offers many excellent opportunities. Personally, I want to immerse (沉浸) myself in the culture and avoid any culture shock (文化冲击). Hopefully, I can find a lucrative (利润丰厚的 / 赚钱的) job in the technology sector soon. I think, working there will genuinely help me broaden one's horizons (开阔眼界). Of course, I am an adaptable (适应性强的) and diligent (勤奋的) person, so I will easily overcome any language barrier (障碍). Even if, I have to start from scratch (白手起家 / 从头开始), it will give me a new perspective (视角) on life.

q2.html:
Describe a city you would like to live in for work purposes. You should say:
Which city it is
What industry is popular there
How you know about this place
And explain why this place is good for your career.

q3.html:
Describe a place you visited that you think would be a good place to work. You should say:
Where the place is
When you visited it
What the lifestyle is like there
And explain why you think working there would be enjoyable.

q1.html:
What kind of job is easy to get in a foreign country?

Op Generally speaking, jobs in the restaurant sector are the easiest to secure, as they require fewer formal qualifications. Re This is because, these entry-level roles usually welcome a highly diverse workforce. Ex For example, international students often find quick work in local cafes to bypass the initial language barrier (语言障碍).

q2.html:
Should young people work abroad?

Op In my view, young people should definitely try to work overseas, because it provides an incredibly inspiring (鼓舞人心的) life experience. Re The main reason is that, international travel fosters rapid personal growth and deepens cultural integration (融合 / 一体化). Ex For instance, living in a foreign melting pot (大熔炉 (多种文化融合)) teaches young professionals how to become independent quickly.

q3.html:
Do Chinese parents encourage their children to work abroad?

Op Admittedly, many Chinese parents do encourage working abroad, as they believe it leads to a more prosperous (繁荣的) future. Re This is due to the fact that, global experience can significantly enhance (提升) a resume in today’s job market. Ex As an illustration, parents often support their children financially so they can benefit from ongoing globalization (全球化).

q4.html:
Why do some people not want to work overseas?

Op On the other hand, some individuals avoid working abroad, because they fear facing isolation or racial discrimination (歧视). Re Furthermore, leaving behind family and friends can ruin their sense of emotional stability and social harmony (和谐). Ex For example, many people strongly prefer the quiet comfort of their hometown rather than adapting (适应) overseas.

q5.html:
What are the benefits of working abroad?

Op Without a doubt, working abroad offers immense benefits, as it helps individuals develop vital cross-cultural communication skills. Re This is because, employees must learn local customs, following the idea that when in Rome, do as the Romans do (入乡随俗). Ex Consequently, this cultural flexibility makes them highly valuable to international corporations (大公司) in the long run.

q6.html:
How does the migration of skilled workers (brain drain) affect the economy of the country they leave?

Op Unfortunately, the phenomenon of brain drain (人才流失) severely impacts a developing nation, because it removes essential talent. Re The primary issue is that, losing highly educated professionals slows down domestic innovation and technological progress. Ex For instance, when top engineers migrate (迁移) to wealthier countries, their home nation struggles to build modern infrastructure (基础设施).

q1.html:
Describe your perfect job. You should say:
What it is
Where you heard about it
What you need to learn to get the job
And explain why you think it is your perfect job.

To begin with, my dream job (理想的工作) is to become an architect, because I am highly adaptable (适应力强的), and I love designing things. Actually, I first heard about this exciting profession from a documentary on television. To get this job, I need to become fully qualified (合格的 / 胜任的) by studying advanced mathematics. I know, it is a very demanding (要求高的 / 费力的) and challenging (充满挑战的) field to enter. However, I want to climb the career ladder (在职业阶梯上晋升) and work for a prestigious (有声望的) company. Ultimately, it is perfect because it is both a lucrative (赚钱的) way to make a living (谋生) and incredibly fulfilling (令人满足的).

q2.html:
Describe a job you would like to have in the future. You should say:
What the job is
What qualifications are required
Whether it is a popular job
And explain why this job appeals to you.

q3.html:
Describe a well-paid job that you would be good at. You should say:
What the job is
What skills you have that match this job
How you would find this job
And explain why you think you would succeed in this role.

q1.html:
What jobs do children want to do when they grow up?

Op Generally speaking, children often dream of becoming doctors or astronauts, as these roles seem highly heroic (英雄的). Re This is largely because, kids are heavily influenced by the media and the exciting cartoons they watch. Ex For instance, watching a superhero movie might spark the initial motivation (动力 / 动机) to save lives when they are older.

q2.html:
What should people consider when choosing jobs?

Op In my view, individuals must consider their personal interests, because passion is essential (必要的) for long-term career satisfaction. Re Furthermore, evaluating the level of job security (工作保障) is absolutely crucial in today's unpredictable global economy. Ex For example, choosing a stable industry prevents the constant terrible fear of sudden unemployment (失业) during a financial crisis.

q3.html:
Is salary the main reason people choose a certain job?

Op Admittedly, salary is a major factor, as everyone needs sufficient income to bring home the bacon (养家糊口). Re However, a high salary alone cannot compensate (补偿) for a toxic work environment or extreme daily stress. Ex Consequently, many employees will actually accept a slightly lower wage if it guarantees a better work-life balance (工作与生活的平衡).

q4.html:
What kind of jobs are well-paid?

Op It is widely acknowledged that, roles in technology and finance are highly lucrative (赚钱的), because they strictly drive the modern economy. Re The core reason is that, these sectors require specialized knowledge and professionals who can think outside the box (跳出框框思考). Ex For instance, top software developers in prosperous (繁荣的) cities receive massive financial bonuses for creating innovative programs.

q5.html:
Do people's ideal jobs change as they grow up?

Op Undeniably, career aspirations (抱负) shift drastically over time, as adults gain a much more realistic understanding of the world. Re As people mature, they realize they do not want to be stuck forever in a boring dead-end job (没前途的工作). Ex As an illustration, a teenager might want to be a singer, but later cautiously chooses a stable accounting career instead.

q6.html:
To what extent does technology (such as AI) threaten traditional job roles in modern society?

Op Without a doubt, the rise of automation (自动化) poses a significant threat, as machines can now perform repetitive tasks perfectly. Re The primary issue is that, this technological shift rapidly accelerates the brain drain (人才流失) in traditional manufacturing sectors. Ex For example, factory workers are frequently replaced by intelligent robots, forcing them to learn completely new digital skills.

q1.html:
Describe a movie you watched recently that you felt disappointed about. You should say:
What it was
Why you decided to watch it
When you watched it
And explain why you felt disappointed about it.

To be honest, I want to talk about a sci-fi movie I saw last weekend, because it was highly anticipated (期待已久的), and I love the actors. Actually, the studio tried to hype up (炒作 / 吹捧) the film with amazing trailers. However, the storyline was completely predictable (可预测的 / 老套的) and deeply confusing (令人困惑的). I think, the acting was very mediocre (平庸的), making the whole experience a huge let-down (令人失望的事). Personally, I felt it was incredibly overrated (被高估的) by the critics. In fact, watching it felt like a complete waste of time (浪费时间) instead of being fulfilling (令人满足的). Ultimately, it failed to meet my demanding (要求高的 / 费力的) expectations for a good film.

q2.html:
Describe a film that did not meet your expectations. You should say:
What the film was called
What you expected to see
What actually happened in the film
And explain why it failed to meet your expectations.

q3.html:
Describe a time you regretted watching a specific movie or show. You should say:
Where you watched it
Who you watched it with
Why you chose it
And explain what made the experience negative.

q1.html:
Do you believe movie reviews?

Op Generally speaking, I only trust reviews from independent critics, as mainstream websites are often paid for marketing. Re This is because, studios use their massive financial influence (影响) to artificially boost the ratings of a blockbuster (大片 (卖座电影)). Ex For instance, many highly rated action films turn out to be completely boring when you actually watch them.

q2.html:
What are the different types of films in your country?

Op In my observation, audiences in my country enjoy a wide variety of films, though comedies are particularly beloved. Re The primary reason is that, people seek lighthearted entertainment as a motivation (动机) to relax after working hard. Ex As an example, the romance and martial arts genre (体裁 / 类型) also attract massive crowds during national holidays.

q3.html:
Are historical films popular in your country? Why?

Op Undeniably, historical films are extremely popular, because they deeply connect the younger generation with their cultural heritage. Re This is largely due to the fact that, these movies often feature stunning traditional cinematography (电影摄影技术) and epic battles. Ex For example, historical stories are frequently a massive box office hit (票房大卖) during the lively Spring Festival season.

q4.html:
Do you think films with famous actors or actresses are more likely to become successful?

Op Admittedly, having a star-studded cast (众星云集的阵容) guarantees initial ticket sales, as loyal fans will always support their favorite celebrities. Re However, fame alone cannot save a movie if the script is poorly written or the directing is weak. Ex Consequently, relying entirely on famous faces instead of good storytelling is a very risky strategy for modern filmmakers.

q5.html:
Why are Japanese animated films so popular?

Op It is widely acknowledged that, Japanese animation is globally successful, because it explores deep philosophical themes beautifully. Re Furthermore, their unique visual style easily keeps audiences completely on the edge of one's seat (由于紧张兴奋而坐立不安). Ex For instance, the smart combination of emotional storytelling and modern digital automation (自动化 (used in context of CGI)) creates true visual masterpieces.

q6.html:
Should directors pay a lot of money to famous actors?

Op In my view, directors should not overpay actors, as this practice severely limits the budget for actual production quality. Re The core issue is that, excessive salaries take away funds needed for proper editing and navigating strict censorship (审查制度) requirements. Ex Therefore, it is much wiser to invest money in talented script writers rather than just paying expensive celebrities.

q1.html:
Describe a person who encouraged you to protect nature. You should say:
Who this person is
How you knew this person
What he/she said or did to encourage you
And explain how you felt about it.

To begin with, I want to talk about my uncle, who is a very conscientious (尽责的 / 有良心的) person, because he constantly teaches me to be eco-friendly (环保的). Actually, he is a truly passionate (热情的) advocate (提倡者) for sustainable (可持续的) living in our hometown. For example, he always tries to do his bit (尽自己的一份力) by picking up litter in the park. I think, he is a genuine nature lover (热爱大自然的人) who makes sure to practice what you preach (言行一致) every day. To be honest, his daily dedication is incredibly inspiring (鼓舞人心的) to me. Therefore, his amazing actions are never predictable (可预测的) and always motivate me.

q2.html:
Describe a person who is very interested in the environment. You should say:
Who they are
What they do to help the environment
How they influence others
And explain what you have learned from them.

q3.html:
Describe an environmental activist or leader you admire. You should say:
Who this person is
What cause they fight for
How they spread their message
And explain why you respect their efforts.

q1.html:
How do people protect the environment?

Op Generally speaking, people protect the environment by recycling daily, because this massively reduces unnecessary waste. Re This is absolutely crucial since, protecting local biodiversity (生物多样性) is necessary for human survival. Ex For instance, even though one person's effort feels like a drop in the ocean (沧海一粟), collective community action makes a huge difference.

q2.html:
Do you think it's important to protect wild animals/nature?

Op Undeniably, it is vital to protect nature, as wildlife strictly maintains our fragile ecological balance. Re The primary reason is that, failing to prioritize conservation (保护 (自然)) will destroy future food sources. Ex Consequently, we must bridge the generation gap (代沟) to ensure older and younger people work together on this urgent issue.

q3.html:
What are the main environmental problems in your country?

Op In my view, the most serious problem is severe air pollution (污染), which deeply affects public health. Re This is largely due to the fact that, rapid industrial growth has prioritized profits over clean air. Ex As an illustration, heavy smog in major cities is just the tip of the iceberg (冰山一角) regarding the damage.

q4.html:
Do you think we should use more renewable energy? Why?

Op Without a doubt, we must aggressively shift to renewable (可再生的) energy, because fossil fuels are rapidly depleting. Re This is absolutely necessary since, traditional dirty energy sources actively wreak havoc (造成严重破坏) on the global climate. Ex For example, utilizing solar panels can significantly reduce our carbon footprint and prevent further deadly temperature increases.

q5.html:
Should schools teach students about environmental protection?

Op Absolutely, schools must teach environmental protection, as children are the future leaders of our planet. Re The core reason is that, early education effectively fosters a lifelong sense of responsibility towards nature. Ex For instance, teaching students about animal extinction (灭绝) helps them genuinely understand the real-world consequences of human negligence.

q6.html:
[New] How effective is international cooperation in solving global environmental crises?

Op It is widely acknowledged that, international cooperation is highly effective, because pollution does not respect national borders. Re This essentially means that, a single country's domestic policies cannot solve global warming alone. Ex Therefore, global treaties have a massive influence (影响) on successfully reducing carbon emissions across the entire industrialized world.

q1.html:
Describe a place with a lot of trees that you would like to visit (e.g., a forest, oasis). You should say:
Where it is
How you knew this place
What it is like
And explain why you would like to visit it.

To begin with, I really want to visit a tranquil (宁静的) bamboo forest in Sichuan, because I need to get away from it all (远离尘嚣), which sounds amazing. Actually, I discovered this picturesque (风景如画的) location while reading an eco-friendly (环保的) travel blog online. Apparently, the scenery is completely breathtaking (惊人的 / 极美的) with endless lush (郁郁葱葱的) green trees. I think, it is quite isolated (偏远的 / 孤立的), making it the perfect place to find some peace and quiet (宁静). Furthermore, the local village focuses heavily on sustainable (可持续的) tourism. Ultimately, I want to visit this place because it is totally off the beaten track (人迹罕至的).

q2.html:
Describe a park or garden in your city that you enjoy visiting. You should say:
Where it is located
How often you go there
What you do there
And explain why you find this place relaxing.

q3.html:
Describe a natural environment (such as a forest or mountain) that impressed you. You should say:
Where this place is
When you went there
Who you went with
And explain why this place was memorable.

q1.html:
Why do people like visiting places with trees or forests?

Op Generally speaking, people visit forests to escape stress, as modern life is often overwhelming. Re This is due to the fact that, rapid urbanization (城市化) creates noisy and crowded living conditions. Ex For example, taking a walk among trees is literally a breath of fresh air (令人耳目一新的人或事) for exhausted city workers.

q2.html:
Are natural views better than city views?

Op In my view, natural views are far superior, because they provide immense psychological benefits. Re The primary reason is that, staring at a concrete jungle (钢筋水泥森林 (城市)) all day increases mental fatigue. Ex As an illustration, looking at green plants has a proven therapeutic (有治疗作用的 / 治愈的) effect on the human brain.

q3.html:
Do all people need some nature?

Op Absolutely, every human needs access to nature, as we are biologically connected to the earth. Re This is crucial since, humanity evolved in a natural habitat (栖息地) long before modern cities existed. Ex Consequently, getting back to nature (回归自然) on weekends is essential for maintaining our emotional health.

q4.html:
Are people hard-wired to protect the environment?

Op Admittedly, not everyone is naturally protective, because greed often overrides environmental concerns. Re The core issue is that, massive corporations frequently prioritize profits over the preservation (保护 / 保存) of natural resources. Ex For instance, ongoing deforestation (森林砍伐) for farming proves that many people value money over ecological balance.

q5.html:
How does rapid urbanization impact the mental health of city dwellers?

Op Undeniably, city expansion heavily impacts mental health, as it separates people from calming green spaces. Re Furthermore, the constant traffic noise and severe pollution (污染) contribute to very high stress levels. Ex Therefore, city residents frequently suffer from anxiety compared to those living in quiet country areas.

q6.html:
Should governments prioritize economic development over the preservation of natural green spaces?

Op It is widely acknowledged that, governments must balance development and nature, because destroying green spaces is permanent. Re This is necessary since, economic growth means nothing if it destroys local biodiversity (生物多样性). Ex For example, building a factory over a park permanently ruins the community's quality of life.

q1.html:
Describe an application (app) you usually use on your phone or computer. You should say:
What it is
When you use it
Why you use it often
And explain how you feel about it.

To begin with, I want to describe WeChat, which is truly an indispensable (不可或缺的) app, because I use it daily. Actually, this innovative (创新的) platform puts everything right at your fingertips (触手可及). For instance, I use it to chat with friends, ensuring I never feel isolated (孤立的). I think, its clean interface is incredibly user-friendly (用户友好的 / 易用的) and highly efficient (高效的). However, the short videos can be quite addictive (令人上瘾的) and I often lose track of time (忘记时间). Sometimes, I am completely glued to the screen (盯着屏幕看) watching breathtaking (惊人的) travel clips. Overall, I feel that this app has completely transformed my social life.

q2.html:
Describe a mobile app that has made your daily life easier. You should say:
What the app is
How it functions
What specific problem it solves for you
And explain why you would recommend it to others.

q3.html:
Describe an app you use for learning or self-improvement. You should say:
What the app teaches
How often you use it
How effective it is
And explain why you prefer using an app over traditional methods.

q1.html:
What is the difference between how young and old people use apps?

Op Generally speaking, young people use apps for entertainment, while older generations focus on practical tools. Re This is because, teenagers have a much higher dependency (依赖) on social media for their daily communication. Ex For instance, a young person might act like a social butterfly (交际花) online, whereas grandparents only use banking apps.

q2.html:
Why do some people dislike using apps?

Op In my view, some individuals dislike apps, because they feel overwhelmed by constant daily notifications. Re The primary reason is that, continuous phone alerts lead to severe information overload (信息过载) and mental fatigue. Ex Furthermore, many older users are deeply concerned that these applications secretly steal their personal privacy (隐私).

q3.html:
What is the most popular app in your country?

Op Without a doubt, the most popular app is WeChat, as it completely dominates digital communication. Re This is largely due to the fact that, the rapid digitalization (数字化) of society requires an all-in-one platform. Ex For example, it facilitates everything from daily business interaction (互动) to paying utility bills with a single tap.

q4.html:
Are people becoming too dependent on mobile apps?

Op Admittedly, society has become overly dependent, because apps now control almost every daily task. Re This reliance is a double-edged sword (双刃剑), as it brings great convenience but severely reduces basic survival skills. Ex As an illustration, due to modern urbanization (城市化), many young people cannot navigate their own city without maps.

q5.html:
To what extent do mobile applications compromise user privacy and data security?

Op Unfortunately, mobile apps heavily compromise data security, as many platforms legally sell user information. Re The core issue is that, greedy companies track our location and browsing habits to generate targeted advertising. Ex Therefore, poor cybersecurity (网络安全) measures often leave individuals completely vulnerable to identity theft and financial fraud.

q6.html:
Will digital tools eventually replace traditional face-to-face services entirely?

Op It is widely acknowledged that, digital tools will not replace humans, because physical contact remains vital. Re This is necessary since, humans naturally crave empathy and real emotional connection during difficult or stressful situations. Ex For instance, speaking to a real doctor provides a therapeutic (有治疗作用的) comfort that an AI robot simply cannot replicate.

q1.html:
Describe a time when you gave advice to others. You should say:
When it was
To whom you gave the advice
What the advice was
And explain why you gave the advice.

To begin with, I want to talk about giving constructive (建设性的) advice to my friend, because he was very hesitant (犹豫的). Actually, he was reluctant (不情愿的) to study for his IELTS exam. Since we were in the same boat (处境相同), I decided to share a word of wisdom (至理名言) with him. I told him that, creating an efficient (高效的) schedule is truly indispensable (不可或缺的) for success. Luckily, he didn't get angry and really decided to take it to heart (往心里去 (认真对待)). I think, he realized my suggestion was very sensible (明智的). Ultimately, he was extremely grateful (感激的) when he finally passed his test.

q2.html:
Describe a time you received useful advice from someone. You should say:
Who gave you the advice
What the situation was
How you applied the advice
And explain how this advice helped you.

q3.html:
Describe a situation where you had to make a difficult decision. You should say:
What the decision was
Who you consulted for help
What the outcome was
And explain how you felt after making the decision.

q1.html:
Should people prepare before giving advice?

Op Generally speaking, people should definitely prepare before giving advice, as words can deeply impact others. Re This is because, offering an objective (客观的) perspective requires careful thought and understanding of the situation. Ex For instance, speaking without preparation often leads to careless comments rather than true wisdom (智慧).

q2.html:
Is it good to ask for advice from strangers online?

Op In my view, asking strangers online is highly risky, because you cannot verify their actual expertise. Re The primary reason is that, trusting anonymous forums is often like the blind leading the blind (问道于盲). Ex Furthermore, sharing detailed personal problems on the internet severely compromises your own digital privacy (隐私).

q3.html:
What are the personalities of people whose job is to give advice to others?

Op Without a doubt, professionals who give advice possess high emotional intelligence, as their job requires empathy. Re This is crucial since, providing effective counseling (咨询 / 辅导) demands immense patience and active listening skills. Ex As an illustration, a good therapist always maintains a calm and supportive attitude during every client interaction (互动).

q4.html:
What are the problems if you ask too many people for advice?

Op Admittedly, asking too many people causes total confusion, because everyone will offer a completely different opinion. Re The core issue is that, conflicting advice creates a mental dilemma (进退两难的困境) and paralyzes your decision-making. Ex Consequently, you might end up deciding to just sit on the fence (保持中立 / 观望) forever without acting.

q5.html:
Is the advice given by older generations still relevant to the problems young people face today?

Op Undeniably, advice from older generations remains highly relevant, as human nature does not change over time. Re Even though technology advances rapidly, the fundamental struggles of human relationships and careers are always the same. Ex Therefore, listening to grandparents prevents young people from having to learn the hard way (通过吃亏学到教训).

q6.html:
To what extent does professional counseling differ from advice given by friends or family?

Op It is widely acknowledged that, professional advice is strictly evidence-based, whereas friends offer purely emotional support. Re This is necessary since, trained experts use proven psychological strategies for proper intervention (干预) in serious crises. Ex For example, a family member might just agree with you, but a professional will challenge your thoughts.

q1.html:
Describe a child who enjoys drawing/painting. You should say:
How you know this child
How often he/she draws

Why do some habits change when people get older?

Op Generally speaking, age brings maturity, and aging bodies demand a healthier lifestyle (生活方式). Re Although old habits die hard (积习难改), severe health scares often force adults to adjust their toxic patterns. Ex For instance, a person might finally stop smoking after realizing the deadly consequence (后果) on their lungs.

q3.html:
How do we develop bad habits?

Op Essentially, poor choices become automatic, because humans naturally seek instant gratification. Re Specifically, the rapid acquisition (养成) of a terrible routine (常规) usually begins as a temporary coping mechanism for daily stress. Ex Therefore, eating sugary chocolate once to feel better quickly turns into a daily sugar addiction.

q4.html:
What can we do to get rid of bad habits?

Op In my opinion, substituting the bad action with a healthy alternative is highly effective. Re Frankly, relying purely on motivation fails; you must consciously change your environment to succeed. Ex As an illustration, an early bird (早起的人) who wants to stop drinking coffee should drink green tea instead.

q5.html:
Do you think successful people always have strict daily routines?

Op Mostly yes, top performers thrive on structure, though some creative geniuses prefer absolute chaos. Re Normally, having a predictable schedule saves mental energy for making extremely important business decisions. Ex However, some famous artists are deeply set in their ways (固执己见) and refuse any strict timetables completely.

q6.html:
Is self-discipline more important than natural talent for success?

Op Absolutely, hard work consistently beats raw talent, especially when talent is lazy. Re Fundamentally, unyielding discipline guarantees continuous improvement, whereas natural gifts eventually plateau without strict practice. Ex For example, a highly disciplined athlete will eventually outrun a naturally fast runner who skips daily training.

q1.html:
Describe an occasion when you were not allowed to use your mobile phone. (Examiner Note: Focus your description on the place/setting where this rule applied) You should say:
When it was
Where it happened
Why you were not allowed to use your phone
And explain how you felt about it.

To start with, I want to talk about my university library, which is incredibly strict (严格的), and where using phones is entirely prohibited (禁止的). Honestly, the librarians are very disciplined (守纪律的) about this policy. Furthermore, any loud noise is considered highly disruptive (破坏性的 / 扰乱的) to studying students. Consequently, they never bend the rules (变通) for anyone. Therefore, I always make sure to follow the rules (遵守规则) carefully. Actually, being a respectful (尊重的) and considerate (体贴的) student is important here. Moreover, distractions are completely detrimental (有害的) to learning. Ultimately, I just keep my voice down (压低声音) to avoid trouble.

q2.html:
Describe a public place where people must be quiet (e.g., Library, Hospital). You should say:
Where it is
How often you go there
Why silence is important there
And explain how you behave when you are there.

q3.html:
Describe a place you visited where there were strict rules. You should say:
Where it was
What the rules were
Why the rules existed
And explain if you agreed with the rules.

q1.html:
How do young and old people use mobile phones differently?

Op Generally speaking, teenagers use phones for entertainment, whereas seniors mainly use them for calling. Re Specifically, young people love the freedom (自由) of social media, which exerts a massive influence (影响) on their daily lives. Ex For instance, an elderly person might just check the weather, while a student watches hours of videos.

q2.html:
Do you think it is necessary to have laws on the use of mobile phones?

Op Absolutely, strict regulations are crucial, especially when public safety is directly involved. Re Fundamentally, maintaining basic law and order (法律与秩序) requires firm restriction (限制) on distracted driving. Ex Therefore, enforcing steep fines ensures driver compliance (服从) and prevents terrible accidents on the highway.

q3.html:
Is it a waste of time to take pictures with mobile phones?

Op In my view, taking a few photos is wonderful, but constantly snapping pictures ruins the moment. Re Unfortunately, some tourists completely cross the line (越界) by blocking pathways just to get a selfie. Ex As a result, they forget basic common courtesy (基本礼貌) and annoy everyone else around them.

q4.html:
Should there be more "phone-free zones" in public spaces?

Op Definitely, establishing quiet areas is a great idea, because it forces people to disconnect. Re Actually, proper social etiquette (礼节) is often forgotten in busy restaurants or cinemas. Ex For example, a phone-free cafe allows customers to enjoy genuine conversations without any digital interruptions.

q5.html:
How has constant connectivity (always being online) affected mental health?

Op Sadly, being always online increases anxiety, and it disrupts normal sleeping patterns. Re Essentially, the negative consequence (后果) of checking notifications at night is chronic exhaustion. Ex Consequently, many teenagers suffer from severe stress because they feel pressured to reply to messages instantly.

q6.html:
Do rules in society limit our freedom or protect us?

Op Ultimately, well-designed laws protect citizens, even though they impose minor daily limits. Re Basically, without a strong authority (权威) enforcing safety guidelines, chaos would easily destroy communities. Ex To illustrate, traffic lights technically restrict movement, but they prevent fatal collisions at busy intersections.

q1.html:
Describe something you plan regularly. You should say:
What it is that you plan regularly
How often you plan it
What you do to plan it
And explain why you plan it and how you feel about planning it.

To begin with, I want to talk about planning my weekly study timetable, which keeps me organized (有条理的), and which prevents me from feeling anxious (焦虑的). Honestly, my school life is incredibly hectic (忙乱的). Therefore, I try to plan ahead (提前计划) every Sunday evening. Actually, I am very strict (严格的) about being punctual (守时的) for classes. Sometimes, I get impatient (不耐烦的) if unexpected events are disruptive (扰乱的) to my routine. During breaks, I just read a book to kill time (消磨时间). Ultimately, getting good grades makes this planning effort worth the wait (值得等待).

q2.html:
Describe a time when you waited for something special. You should say:
What you were waiting for
How long you waited
What you did while waiting
And explain how you felt when it finally happened.

q3.html:
Describe a time when you were very busy. You should say:
When it was
Why you were so busy
How you managed your time
And explain how you felt after the busy period was over.

q1.html:
Is making plans important?

Op Absolutely, setting clear goals is crucial, because it gives people direction in life. Re Essentially, strong time management (管理) prevents terrible procrastination (拖延症) and lowers daily stress. Ex For instance, writing a simple to-do list helps students finish their homework much faster.

q2.html:
Should children plan their future careers?

Op Definitely, teenagers should start thinking about jobs early, but they should remain flexible. Re Ultimately, making education a top priority (优先事项) helps them choose the right university courses later. Ex However, since time flies (光阴似箭) and industries change quickly, their plans will naturally evolve.

q3.html:
Do you think it is important to be a patient person?

Op Without a doubt, staying calm is vital, since rushing often leads to careless mistakes. Re In fact, true efficiency (效率) requires a steady pace rather than frantic panic. Ex Therefore, doctors must remain completely patient during a long surgery to ensure the patient's safety.

q4.html:
Why do some people dislike waiting?

Op Honestly, people hate delays, because they feel their precious time is being stolen. Re Specifically, a strict restriction (限制) on someone's daily schedule (日程安排) causes extreme frustration. Ex For example, commuters get very angry when a late train makes them miss an important morning meeting.

q5.html:
Does modern technology make us more impatient?

Op Admittedly, fast internet makes us expect instant results, which lowers our tolerance for delays. Re Consequently, when a web page takes ten seconds to load, we struggle with compliance (顺从 / 遵守) and get annoyed. Ex As a result, people frequently try to beat the clock (赶时间) instead of enjoying the current moment.

q6.html:
"Time is money." Do you agree with this statement? Why or why not?

Op To a large extent, I agree, because wasted hours equal lost earning opportunities. Re However, resting is also valuable, so perhaps we should say better late than never (迟做总比不做好) when finding balance. Ex For instance, working constantly creates wealth, but skipping sleep will eventually destroy your health.

q1.html:
Describe a competition (e.g., TV, school, or sports) that you took part in. You should say:
What the competition was
When it took place
What you had to do
And explain how you felt about participating in it.

First of all, I want to describe a school debate tournament, which was highly prestigious (有声望的), and where the atmosphere was incredibly intense (激烈的). Honestly, I felt quite anxious (焦虑的) beforehand. Actually, the event was very well organized (有组织的). Furthermore, my opponents were extremely competitive (竞争激烈的 / 好胜的). However, I decided to give it my all (全力以赴) because I wanted to be in it to win it (志在必得). Consequently, I practiced my speech for weeks. Surprisingly, our team managed to win hands down (轻而易举地获胜). Ultimately, feeling victorious (胜利的) and triumphant (欢欣鼓舞的) on stage was simply amazing.

q2.html:
Describe a prize that you won. You should say:
What the prize was
How you won it
Who you were competing against
And explain how you felt when you received it.

q3.html:
Describe a live sports match or competition you watched. You should say:
What the sport was
Where you watched it
Who was playing
And explain why it was exciting to watch.

q1.html:
Why do people like to participate in competitions?

Op Generally, people enjoy contests, because they love testing their limits against others. Re Fundamentally, a healthy rivalry (竞争 / 敌对) provides immense motivation and boosts personal determination (决心). Ex For example, runners often achieve their fastest times during a real race rather than during lonely practice sessions.

q2.html:
Is it good to teach children to be competitive at a young age?

Op In my opinion, mild competition is fine, but intense pressure hurts young minds. Re Essentially, kids need to learn good sportsmanship (体育精神) rather than obsessing over winning. Ex Therefore, emphasizing fun creates a win-win situation (双赢局面) where every child feels valued regardless of the final score.

q3.html:
What skills can people learn from team sports that they cannot learn from individual sports?

Op Undeniably, group sports teach incredible teamwork (团队合作), which individual sports simply cannot provide. Re Specifically, players learn strict cooperation (合作) and trust by relying on their peers. Ex For instance, a soccer player must pass the ball unselfishly to secure a victory for the whole squad.

q4.html:
Do you think companies encourage competition between employees? Is this healthy?

Op Admittedly, many businesses push internal contests, yet this often ruins office harmony. Re Actually, if management (管理) makes sales targets the only priority (优先事项), employees might sabotage each other. Ex Consequently, it is usually much healthier to reward collective team success rather than praising cut-throat individuals.

q5.html:
Why are reality TV competitions (like singing or cooking shows) so popular globally?

Op Honestly, television contests are engaging, because viewers love dramatic human stories. Re Furthermore, watching ordinary people compete on a level playing field (公平竞争的环境) is deeply inspiring. Ex As an illustration, a singing show allows an unknown amateur to become a global superstar overnight.

q6.html:
Is "winning" the only thing that matters in professional sports?

Op Unfortunately, winning is heavily prioritized, though fan entertainment is also crucial. Re Essentially, professional athletes must constantly keep their eye on the ball (保持专注) to secure lucrative contracts. Ex As a result, a football coach will quickly be fired if his team loses multiple games, despite playing beautifully.

q1.html:
Describe a neighbor you have who is interesting or helpful. You should say:
Who this person is
How long you have known them
How often you see them
And explain why you think they are interesting/helpful.

To begin with, I want to talk about my next-door neighbor (隔壁邻居), who is incredibly neighborly (睦邻友好的), and who always smiles. Honestly, he is a very helpful (乐于助人的) and generous (慷慨的) elderly man. Actually, some people in our building are quite nosy (爱管闲事的) or overly competitive (爱攀比的). However, he is just remarkably considerate (体贴的) without any intense (强烈的) drama. For instance, he will gladly keep an eye on (照看) my cat when I travel. Furthermore, he is always ready to lend a hand (伸出援手) with heavy groceries. Ultimately, having someone so reliable living nearby is a huge blessing.

q2.html:
Describe a person who contributes a lot to your local community. You should say:
Who the person is
What they do for the community
Why they do it
And explain how their actions affect the neighborhood.

q3.html:
Describe a time you helped a neighbor. You should say:
What the problem was
How you helped
What the result was
And explain how you felt about helping them.

q1.html:
What are the qualities of a "good neighbor"?

Op Generally speaking, a good neighbor is quiet, and they respect boundaries. Re In fact, the old saying good fences make good neighbors (保持距离才能和睦相处) highlights the deep need for personal privacy. Ex Therefore, being polite but not overly intrusive creates the most peaceful living environment for the entire community (社区).

q2.html:
How has the relationship between neighbors changed compared to the past?

Op Undeniably, people are much less connected now, because they live busier lives. Re Historically, close village cooperation (合作) was essential for survival, but modern convenience has ruined that. Ex Consequently, today's rapid urbanization (城市化) means people often do not even know the names of people living next door.

q3.html:
Why do people in big cities often not know their neighbors?

Op Mainly, high-rise apartments create physical barriers, which severely limit daily interaction (互动). Re Furthermore, the fast pace of city life creates a sad sense of social isolation (孤立). Ex For instance, commuters arrive home exhausted and immediately lock their doors instead of chatting in the hallway.

q4.html:
Do you think community centers are important for a neighborhood?

Op Absolutely, local centers are incredibly important, as they provide a shared gathering space. Re Essentially, they help build strong relationships by hosting fun events that feel very close to home (切身相关的). Ex As an illustration, a local hall offering free dance classes helps strangers become fast friends.

q5.html:
How can neighbors help each other in times of crisis or emergency?

Op During disasters, neighbors are the first responders, because they are physically closest. Re Fundamentally, when a storm hits, people must drop any petty rivalry (对立) and quickly look out for each other (守望相助). Ex For example, sharing emergency food supplies and checking on elderly residents ensures everyone's basic security (安全).

q6.html:
Should there be laws to control noisy neighbors?

Op Definitely, strict noise regulations are absolutely necessary, since constant loud sounds ruin mental health. Re Actually, everyone deserves a quiet place to sleep after a long, exhausting day of work. Ex Therefore, police should be able to fine people who blast loud music at two in the morning.

q1.html:
Describe a place near water (such as a river, lake, or the ocean) that you enjoyed visiting. You should say:
Where this place was
What you did there
Who you went with
And explain why you liked this place.

To begin with, I want to describe a serene (宁静的) bay, which is incredibly breathtaking (美得惊人的), and which I visited last summer. Honestly, the water there is absolutely crystal clear (清澈见底) and perfectly safe for swimming. Furthermore, the local people are extremely neighborly (友好的) and welcoming to all tourists. Actually, the beach is just a stone's throw away (近在咫尺) from a very comfortable hotel. During the day, I simply loved to soak up the sun (沐浴阳光) on the warm sand. Moreover, the cool ocean breeze felt so refreshing (令人耳目一新的). Thankfully, the beautiful coastal (沿海的) environment was not polluted (被污染的) at all. Ultimately, nature was very generous (慷慨的) to this stunning place.

q2.html:
Describe a holiday destination you would like to visit. You should say:
Where it is located
How you would travel there
What you would do there
And explain why this place attracts you.

q3.html:
Describe a place in your country that is famous for its natural beauty. You should say:
Where it is
What it looks like
Why it is famous
And explain if you think it is a good place for tourists.

q1.html:
Why do so many people like to live near the water?

Op Generally speaking, coastal areas offer beautiful views, and they provide a very relaxing lifestyle. Re Furthermore, living near the ocean gives people easy access to fresh air and fun water sports. Ex For example, many individuals move to maritime (海事的 / 沿海的) cities specifically to enjoy sailing or daily beach walks.

q2.html:
What are the dangers of water pollution to society?

Op Undeniably, contaminated rivers threaten human health, and they severely damage the local biodiversity (生物多样性). Re Consequently, toxic chemicals from rapid urbanization (城市化) can easily poison drinking water supplies. Ex As a result, poor water security (安全) leads to terrible disease outbreaks in many developing nations.

q3.html:
Should the government limit tourism in environmentally sensitive areas?

Op Absolutely, strict limits are necessary, because crowds can easily destroy fragile natural habitats. Re Fundamentally, prioritizing environmental conservation (保护) is much more important than generating short-term tourism profits. Ex Therefore, capping visitor numbers helps turn the tide (扭转局势) against severe ecological degradation.

q4.html:
How important is water transportation (shipping) to the global economy?

Op In my opinion, shipping is absolutely vital, since it enables massive international trade. Re Actually, moving heavy cargo via ocean transportation (运输) is significantly cheaper than using airplanes. Ex For instance, giant cargo ships continuously transport millions of tons of electronics and clothing across the globe daily.

q5.html:
Do you think future wars will be fought over water resources?

Op Sadly, this is highly likely, as clean water is becoming incredibly scarce worldwide. Re Essentially, climate change and overpopulation are rapidly depleting every vital freshwater resource (资源). Ex Consequently, neighboring countries sharing a single drying river might easily go to war to survive.

q6.html:
How can individuals reduce their water consumption in daily life?

Op Realistically, small daily habits matter, even if they seem like a drop in the ocean (沧海一粟). Re Moreover, fixing leaky pipes and taking much shorter showers can collectively save thousands of gallons. Ex By doing this, individual citizens can truly make waves (引起轰动 / 产生重大影响) in global water preservation efforts.

q1.html:
Describe a uniform you have worn (e.g., at school or work). You should say:
When you wore it
What it looked like
Who provided it
And explain how you felt about wearing it.

To begin with, I want to describe my high school uniform, which was quite formal (正式的), and which I wore every day. Honestly, the dark blue color looked very serene (宁静的) and professional. Actually, the blazer was tailored to fit like a glove (极度合身) on me. Furthermore, wearing it made me feel quite stylish (时髦的) and incredibly elegant (优雅的). Conversely, some students thought the design was totally outdated (过时的). However, I liked it because the cotton fabric was highly comfortable (舒适的) and refreshing (清爽的) in summer. Ultimately, I always looked dressed to kill (盛装打扮) for school. Overall, I felt like a true trendsetter (引领潮流的人) in my class.

q2.html:
Describe a piece of clothing you like to wear on special occasions. You should say:
What it is
Where you bought it
When you wear it
And explain why you like it.

q3.html:
Describe a traditional piece of clothing from your country. You should say:
What it is called
Who wears it
When people usually wear it
And explain the cultural significance of this clothing.

q1.html:
Why do some companies and schools require people to wear uniforms?

Op Generally speaking, uniforms enforce strict uniformity (一致性), which instantly creates a sense of equality. Re Specifically, removing brand-name clothing prevents poorer students from becoming targets for cruel bullying. Ex As a result, a shared identity (身份) helps everyone focus on their actual work rather than their fashion choices.

q2.html:
Do you think people are judged too much by the clothes they wear?

Op Unfortunately, society heavily judges appearances, because clothes often signal a person's financial status (地位). Re Basically, human beings naturally form quick first impressions based entirely on visual cues. Ex Therefore, people tend to judge a book by its cover (以貌取人) when they meet someone dressed in cheap clothing.

q3.html:
How has fashion changed in your country in recent years?

Op Undeniably, fashion has become much more diverse, and western styles are extremely popular. Re Furthermore, young people use clothing as a powerful form of bold self expression (表达) today. Ex For instance, teenagers now mix traditional garments with modern sneakers to create totally unique outfits.

q4.html:
Is it necessary to follow the latest fashion trends?

Op In my opinion, chasing trends is completely unnecessary, as personal comfort matters more. Re Actually, being a slave to fashion (时尚奴隶) is exhausting and extremely expensive over time. Ex Consequently, a fashion victim (盲目追求时尚的人) will waste thousands of dollars buying bizarre clothes they only wear once.

q5.html:
Do you think expensive designer clothes are worth the money?

Op Honestly, luxury brands are rarely worth the huge price tag, though their quality is good. Re Essentially, you are mostly paying for the famous logo rather than the actual textile (纺织品) itself. Ex Therefore, you can easily find durable, stylish clothes at normal stores for a fraction of the cost.

q6.html:
Does the "fast fashion" industry (cheap, disposable clothing) harm the environment?

Op Absolutely, fast fashion is disastrous, because it pollutes rivers and creates massive waste. Re Fundamentally, throwing away cheap shirts constantly drains every natural resource (资源) we have left. Ex Instead, promoting clothing recycling and mindful conservation (节约) is the only way to save our planet.

q1.html:
Describe an important traditional festival in your country. You should say:
When the festival takes place
What people do during this festival
What special food is eaten
And explain why this festival is important.

To begin with, I want to describe the Spring Festival, which is highly traditional (传统的), and which brings families together. Honestly, the atmosphere is incredibly festive (节日的) and vibrant (充满活力的) everywhere. Actually, eating dumplings together is a deeply meaningful (有意义的) and ceremonial (仪式的) custom. Furthermore, we always dress in formal (正式的) and elegant (优雅的) red clothing to welcome the new year. Later, my friends and I usually go out to paint the town red (狂欢) with fireworks. Consequently, we always manage to have a ball (玩得开心). Ultimately, since the more the merrier (人越多越热闹), large gatherings are simply the best part.

q2.html:
Describe a party or celebration you attended. You should say:
What the celebration was for (e.g., wedding, birthday)
Who was there
What happened at the party
And explain whether you enjoyed it or not.

q3.html:
Describe a national holiday in your country. You should say:
What day it is
The history behind it
How you usually spend this day
And explain why it is significant to your nation.

q1.html:
Is globalization causing young people to lose interest in traditional festivals?

Op Admittedly, Western holidays are trending, but local traditions remain deeply important to the youth. Re While globalization (全球化) introduces new celebrations, young people still respect their roots to maintain cultural identity (认同感). Ex For instance, teenagers might celebrate Christmas for fun, but they still prioritize the Lunar New Year.

q2.html:
Do you think festivals have become too commercialized (focused on money/shopping)?

Op Unfortunately, heavy marketing has ruined holidays, because businesses only care about maximizing their profits. Re Consequently, the extreme commercialization (商业化) of events like Valentine's Day pressures people into buying expensive, useless gifts. Ex As a result, the original emotional expression (表达) of love is entirely replaced by pure consumerism.

q3.html:
Why are public holidays important for the workforce?

Op Undeniably, days off are crucial, since they prevent severe burnout among exhausted employees. Re Fundamentally, returning to work feeling rested and in high spirits (兴高采烈) drastically improves overall productivity. Ex Therefore, a long weekend allows stressed office workers to properly rest and spend time with their families.

q4.html:
How do festivals help to preserve a country's culture?

Op Essentially, annual celebrations pass down customs, which actively prevents historical knowledge from dying completely. Re Furthermore, practicing old rituals guarantees the preservation (保存) of a nation's unique intangible heritage (遗产). Ex For example, teaching children how to make traditional mooncakes helps to keep tradition alive (传承传统) forever.

q5.html:
Should immigrants learn about the festivals of their new country?

Op Absolutely, learning local customs is vital, as it promotes smooth social integration (融合). Re Actually, participating in national events helps newcomers feel included in the modern cultural melting pot (大熔炉). Ex As an illustration, an expat joining a local Thanksgiving dinner quickly builds strong bonds with their new neighbors.

q6.html:
What is the difference between how children and adults enjoy festivals?

Op Generally speaking, kids love the games, whereas adults appreciate the rare chance to relax. Re Basically, children focus entirely on receiving fun toys or eating lots of sweet candy. Ex Conversely, tired parents enjoy festivals simply by catching up with old friends over a very quiet meal.
